articles.name: Create Amazon Developer Accounts
articles.title: Create Amazon Developer Accounts
articles.body:
Creating An Amazon Developer Account

1. Go to https://developer.amazon.com and click on "Developer Console" in the top right and then on "Create your Amazon Developer account" on the bottom of the screen.

2. After completing the form, get the verification code from your email and verify the account.

3. After enrolling in the Developer Program, you’ll be able to login to the Amazon Developer Account (see below).

4. Click on "Settings" in the top right.

5. Select "User Permissions" from the secondary navigation bar that appears.

6. Click on "Add New" in the lower right.

7. Enter your provided "@mazdigital.com" email address, select "Yes" for Administrator permissions, then click Save.

articles.name: Create Google Developer Account
articles.title: Create Google Developer Account
articles.body:
Creating A Google Play Developer Account

1. Navigate to https://developers.google.com/

2. Click Product Index > Develop > Android

3. In the top right of the screen, click ‘Play Console’

4. Follow the steps to Accept the Developer Agreement and set up your account.

5. Once account set up is completed, click ‘Settings’ in the Google Play Console.

6. Click Users & Permissions, then “Invite New User”

7. Enter the exact email address that MAZ has provided (ie, yourcompany@mazdigital.com), set the permissions to “Administrator” and “Send the invitation”

8. Confirm that all of your information is visible under Account Details.

NOTE: If you have in-app purchases, you must also sign up for a Google Merchant Account - https://www.google.com/retail/solutions/merchant-center/

articles.name: Create Apple Developer Accounts
articles.title: Create Apple Developer Accounts
articles.body:
Creating An Apple Developer Account

1. Go to https://developer.apple.com/ and click “Account” in the top right.

2. Click “Create Apple ID” (this ID will be used to manage your app, do not use a personal account) and fill out the required information.

3. After completing the form, get the verification code from your email and verify the account.

4. You’ll be redirected to Apple Developer login page. Enter your account info, hit submit and on the following page, check the box under the Apple Developer Agreement.

5. Enroll in the Apple Developer Program. You will be required to supply certain information which listed here - https://developer.apple.com/programs/enroll/

6. After enrolling in the Developer Program, email success@mazdigital.com and MAZ will create your MAZ Dev Admin account email address. You’ll also now be able to login to iTunes Connect (detailed below).

7. Once we confirm your MAZ Dev Account email, you should invite MAZ as an “administrator” for the account. Click People > Invite People > enter the exact email address that MAZ has provided (ie, yourcompany@mazdigital.com).

8. Important: Notify your account manager that you have sent this invitation. It expires in 24 hours, and the email inbox is not regularly monitored.

Authorizing MAZ In iTunes Connect

1. Navigate to https://itunesconnect.apple.com/login and enter your Apple ID.

2. Click “Users and Roles” and on the following screen click the ‘+’ sign to invite a new user.

3. Enter the exact email address that MAZ has provided (ie, yourcompany@mazdigital.com) and click Next

4. Check “Admin”, click Next and then Save.

5. Important: Notify your account manager that you have sent this invitation. It expires in 24 hours, and the email inbox is not regularly monitored.

articles.name: Introducing Template Designer
articles.title: Introducing Template Designer
articles.body:
Introducing a powerful and efficient way to customize your templates for different article types instantly through MAZ. Here is just a brief overview of all of the powerful productivity features that Template Designer unlocks for your team:

  • Create and manage infinite templates
  • Assign templates per feed
  • Assign templates per article
  • Drag & drop reordering of elements
  • WYSIWYG style editor
  • Inline preview of various device orientations
  • Automatic media queries + breakpoint support
  • Infinite custom fonts
  • Integrates with existing CMS tags
  • Instant previews of any article
  • Share previews with team members
  • Publish to code instantly

In this guide, you will learn how Template Designer works, dive deeper into the different features and how to publish your first custom template.

Getting Started

Upon logging in that the MAZ Control, hover over Media Manager in the navigation and click on Template Designer.

This will take you into the main Template Designer control center. Immediately, you will be presented with three different options

DEFAULT MAZ TEMPLATE

The MAZ default template that your app uses by default. This template is already active for all of your layouts.

FONTS

Where you manage all of the different fonts that your app uses and upload new ones

+ TEMPLATE

Create a new template from scratch

Default, Active and Duplicate

You’ll notice within the Template Designer control center, you have toggles for DEFAULT, ACTIVE and DUPLICATE. There must always be one template that is the default and that is active.

DEFAULT

This allows you to assign any template as your default for any article in your app. You can’t change the default until you have another template

ACTIVE

This template is live in the app environment for all end users. You can now easily enable and disable templates with the click of a button

DUPLICATE

If you want to keep all of the attributes of an existing template but tweak a few elements, you can easily duplicate the template to create another version

Fonts

Before you get started creating new templates, we do recommend squaring away which fonts you want to have access to.

When you click into FONTS, you won’t see any fonts listed. That means your templates are currently using the default device font library (for example San Francisco for iOS).

The cool thing about Template Designer is now you can host your brand’s fonts and experiment with different font styles to your heart’s content.

To add a new font, click + FONT

Template Designer currently supports the following Free Google Fonts which you can add to your app’s font library directly in the Font selector; no need to download separate files.

If you have licenses for custom fonts, you can upload it directly into the back end. Template Designer accepts both .ttf and .otf font files.

Once you have activated a new font, all of your templates will have the ability to access those fonts moving forward for your headlines, body text, etc. You can always add new fonts later.

Creating Your First Template

Once you have your fonts ready to go, click +Template from the main control center to start designing your first template. You can create multiple, and use them accordingly based on the type of content you are sharing. You can also create separate layouts for both mobile, tablet, portrait and landscape orientations.

First, name your template. We recommend picking a name that describes the look that you are going for (ex: HEADLINE at the TOP) so when you apply it to content, you’ll know the primary function of the template.

Supported Styles

Disclaimer - Not all of your styles will be automatically linked to your templates

Then, click on each item to adjust your customizations. Here are the different elements that you can customize:

  • Top Margin
  • Bottom Margin
  • Header Media
  • Date
  • Headline
  • Sub-headline
  • Byline
  • Paragraph
  • Links
  • H1
  • H2
  • H3
  • H4
  • H5
  • Horizontal Line
  • Pull Quotes
  • Ordered Lists
  • Unordered Lists
  • Inline Image
  • Image Captions
  • Inline Video
  • Video Captions
  • Advertisements
  • Credits

Depending on its type, each element has different editing options, detailed below.

Element Editor

For each of the different types, you now have granular control over how these elements are rendered within the app and interact with other elements in the articles themselves. Below, you will find a list of all of the different ways you can customize your content.

TEXT

  • Display - On, Off
  • Placement - Left, Center, Right
  • Margins - Left, Top, Bottom, Right
  • Line Height - Proportional to font size
  • Character Spacing - Includes negative values
  • Font Style - Automatically pulled from the Font Library
  • Font Size - 0 to 100
  • Font Color - Hex values
  • Caps Rules - Case sensitive, Upper case, Lower case

LISTS

Ordered - Same as Text

  • List Style - Decimal, Lowercase Alphabet, Uppercase Alphabet, Lowercase Roman Numerals, Uppercase Roman Numerals

Unordered - Same as Text

  • List Style - Disc, Circle, Square, None

MEDIA

  • Margins - Left, Top, Bottom, Right

LINK

  • Font Color - Default link color
  • Active Color - Post click color

HORIZONTAL LINE

  • Margins - Left, Top, Bottom, Right
  • Thickness - Pixels
  • Line Color - Hex values

ADVERTISEMENT

  • Margins - Top, Bottom
  • Ad Label - On, Off
  • Label Text - Editable

With each new product release cycle, we will continue to add more editing capabilities, so please contact us if there is something you would like added to the element editor.

Drag & Drop

Now you can easily shift the order elements around in your templates: just simply drag and drop each element to place it where you want.

Drag and drop applies to the following elements: HEADER MEDIA, DATE, HEADLINE, SUB-HEADLINE and BYLINE. You’ll notice that you can’t adjust the order of style elements such as H1 text or links. since those are embedded within the content itself.

The game changer is once you have decided on an element order that you like, you can now assign it to any content that you publish within your application. You can also easily make any tweaks and publish any formatting changes automatically across all of the relevant content.

Apply To All Devices + Orientations

Template Designer supports different layout options for 4 different device view configurations:

  • Mobile Portrait
  • Mobile Landscape
  • Tablet Portrait
  • Tablet Landscape

When this box is checked, all applicable style changes made to the element will be applied across the board to both Mobile and Tablet: Portrait and Landscape formats. Some styles, such as line height, aren’t applicable across devices by design since what works on mobile won’t translate to tablet.

IMPORTANT

You’ll notice that if you uncheck the box in one section such as Mobile Portrait, it will automatically uncheck it across all viewports. To link them back, you can recheck them at any point, but remember that it will then override any existing formatting.

Save & Preview

With the Save & Preview function, you can now preview any link that is hosted on your website or within the MAZ Media Manager and see how your new template will be rendered in any device orientation.

MAZ generates a preview link that you can view instantly in browser or email to yourself and anybody on your team. These new collaboration tools should be a game changer to QAing your content on the relevant device types and improving cross team collaboration.

NOTE

Saving is only available to MAZ users that have upgraded their plan to include Template Designer. Please contact success@mazdigital.com to unlock these features in MAZ.

Assigning Templates to Content

Template Designer gives you the power to assign templates across an entire feed or pick and choose individual articles.

Once you are satisfied with how your template looks, head into Experience Creator and easily update what you currently have in place. Within your RSS and Feed Builder Sections, simply click “Edit” and your new template will be available to select and assign to any feed that you link.

Additionally, you can now assign that template to any individual articles that you create within Media Manager or link to within Feed Builder.

You also have quick access to template preview so you can quickly check out your content and/or forward to a colleague.

Save vs. Publish

Once your template is finished and ready to be launched, you’ll notice two different CTAs in the top right of Template Designer: PUBLISH and SAVE. There is a key distinction between the two.

SAVE

Saves all of your changes to MAZ. Templates can only be viewed within MAZ environments. You’ll notice that if you have unpublished changes, there will be an alert above the buttons

PUBLISH

Publishes your changes to your live application and end users. Any content that has been assigned to the template will be updated accordingly. No need to resubmit your app to the app store!

articles.name: Targeted Banners: Per Section or Feed
articles.title: Targeted Banners: Per Section or Feed
articles.body:
Within Experience Creator, you can manage your Banner Groups in Banners. You can create groups of banners by simply clicking on +Group. These groups can be targeted at different sections or feeds in your app for mobile, tablet, and OTT.  

To target a specific Section, simply tap Setup to choose what Banner Group to display:

And to target a specific Content, expand “Advertising Options” while setting up your Content to choose Banners:

articles.name: Add Video Content
articles.title: Add Video Content
articles.body:
Once you have created your Section, click into the Section Box. (ie: click Runners)

Here you will see an option to add +Section to create a Sub-Section, or +Content to add the Content source for this section you've just created.

Click +Content and begin filling out the form: First name your Content, then choose the Content Type (source of Content), Video Options: MRSS, Feed Builder Live Video, Simulated Live Video


...If choosing MRSS:

1. Insert your Feed URL
2. Choose whether you want your feed to be Free or Locked.
3. If Locked, then choose if you want to include an In-App Purchase and/or Subscription Paywall, and continue to choose if you'd like to implement Timed Access, and the price of payment.
4. Choose whether to Share Content URLs (allowing users to share from your feed)
5. Write in your Sub-Title and Description
6. Then choose your TV Specific options:
7. Layout: choose between Standard Grid, Jumbo Grid, and Detail View (examples under Design Section)
8. Choose Thumbnail Orientation (Landscape or Horizontal)
9. Background Type: Choose between Basic Black, Gradient (where you will choose two colors), Image, or Video (which will play on loop in background) of app

10. Upload Feed Image for vertical or horizontal, minimum size 300p x300x, PNG or JPG
11. Upload Logo, height 150p, transparent background, 72dpi, PNG
12. Choose whether to display on top shelf
13. Choose where Visible On whether just TV or also Mobile/Tablet
14. If choose Mobile/Tablet, it will take you back up the page where you will need to choose your Theme (Cards, Edge, Mosaic, Text, List, Carousal, Detail View), will require a Feed Image and Logo
15. Choose whether you want this Content Feed Active on app, to Show Banners, Show Ads, and if so, if to integrate with SpotX Sponsored

....if Choosing Feed Builder

1. Choose whether you want your feed to be Free or Locked.
2. If Locked, then choose if you want to include an In-App Purchase and/or Subscription Paywall, and continue to choose if you'd like to implement Timed Access, and the price of payment.
3. Choose whether to Share Content URLs (allowing users to share from your feed)
4. Write in your Sub-Title and Description
5. Choose where Visible On whether just TV or also Mobile/Tablet
6. If choose Mobile/Tablet, decide if you'd like on Apple Watch
7. Choose whether you want this Content Feed Active on app, to Show Banners, Show Ads, and if so, what ad integrations
8. Review Advanced Options

After clicking Save... Click into the Content Menu you just created, and you will view the next menu, where you can start Feed Builder and add in +Item (Image or Video)

>>

Once you choose which +Item, you add in the Source (URL or Media Manager) the Title, Sub-Title, Description, Tags, and Feed Image vertical or horizontal, minimum size 300p x300x, PNG or JPG


....if Choosing Live Video or Simulated Live Video
2. Add in the Feed URL
3. Choose whether you want your feed to be Free or Locked.
4. If Locked, then choose if you want to include an In-App Purchase and/or Subscription Paywall, and continue to choose if you'd like to implement Timed Access, and the price of payment.
5. Choose whether to Share Content URLs (allowing users to share from your feed)
6. Write in your Sub-Title and Description
7. Choose where Visible On whether just TV or also Mobile/Tablet
8. If choose Mobile/Tablet, decide if you'd like on Apple Watch
9. Upload Feed Image for vertical or horizontal, minimum size 300p x300x, PNG or JPG (for TV + Mobile)
7. Choose whether you want this Content Feed Active on app, to Show Banners, Show Ads, and if so, what ad integrations
8. Review Advanced Options in regards to release date and deeplinks

articles.name: Feed Builder 101
articles.title: Feed Builder 101
articles.body:
How to Use Feed Builder

Go to Experience Creator, and create a +Section. Once you have a Section named that you want to add content to, tap into the Section (by hitting the name of the section on left). From there you can tap +Content,





There you will be able to choose Feed Builder as a content type to source from. Proceed to continue to fill out the form and click Save.

Once you have your Content type created, you click into that Content in order to start Feed Builder.

From here, you can add in your +Item to build your feed.

Adding Articles

1. Click the +Item

2. Select Article

3. Choose Source (URL, Media Manager)

4. In the URL field, copy+paste the URL of the article

5. The system will pull the title, sub title, description and tags from the URL, but you can change it if you would like

6. Add Feed Image (horizontal or vertical) minimum size 300x300p, 72dpi, JPG

5. Click Save

Adding Image

1. Click the +Item

2. Select Image

3. Choose Source (URL, Media Manager)

4. In the URL field, copy+paste the URL of the article

5. The system will pull the title, sub title, description and tags from the URL, but you can change it if you would like

6. Add Feed Image (horizontal or vertical) minimum size 300x300p, 72dpi, JPG

5. Click Save

Adding Video

1. Click the +Item

2. Select Video

3. Paste URL

4. The system will pull the title, sub title, description and tags from the URL, but you can change it if you would like

6. Add Feed Image (horizontal or vertical) minimum size 300x300p, 72dpi, JPG

5. Click Save


Adding Header:

1. Click the +Item

2. Select Header

3. Enter Header Text, this will be used to separate sections of your feed

4. Click Save

Adding Magazine Ads

1. Click the +Item

2. Select Magazine Ad

3. Upload Ad image, min size 300x300 p, 72dpi, JPG or PNG

4. Enter URL

5. Enter Ad Name

6. Click Save


Adding Deeplink

1. Click the +Item

2. Select Deeplink

3. Deeplink to... Choose where in the app to Deeplink to

4. Enter Title

5. Enter Sub-Title

6. Enter Description

7. Enter Tags

8. Upload Feed Image (horizontal, vertical), min size 300x300 p, 72dpi, JPG

9. Click Save

Adding a PDF:

1. Click the +Item

2. Select PDF

3. Upload PDF

4. Enter Title

5. Enter Sub-Title

6. Enter Description

7. Enter Tags

8. Upload Feed Image (horizontal, vertical), min size 300x300 p, 72dpi, JPG

9. Click Save

articles.name: Content Access
articles.title: Content Access
articles.body:
Content Access

When you're in Experience Creator and are creating Sections and Contents, you will see in the Edit Content window that you can determine how users can access a menu. A 'Free' content will be open to all app users. A 'Locked' content will be visible as well, but users will need to pass a paywall to unlock it.

Access Types

Subscription/Paywall - users that have an active subscription or membership will be automatically granted access to the content. If not, they will be prompted to subscribe before viewing the content.

In-App Purchase - users must pay to access the content regardless of their membership status

Both - users without memberships will be prompted to either subscribe or to purchase the content

Timed Access

Using Timed Access you can offer free access to the menu for a specified number of minutes. As soon as the user opens a piece of content, the timer begins. If they exit, the timer will stop and resume counting when the user returns to any content in the menu. In the example below, the user has 1 minute and 54 seconds of free access remaining.

Be thoughtful about how much time you will allow. How much content will hook your readers? Are we giving away too much free access?

Turning on Timed Access is completely up to you, but it is recommended by MAZ. Nothing drives conversions more than being able to test out the product and feeling the pressure of the countdown.

Price

Set the price for unlocking the menu. This price setting is not universal, so think about the price in terms of the individual menu and how much content you are offering.

articles.name: Sections 101
articles.title: Sections 101
articles.body:
Sections — the buttons across the bottom of the app

Sections are high level categories used to segment and organize your content. We have included dozens of Section Names, so think about what categories would make sense for your content. These buttons are visible on every screen, it may be helpful to think Section Names as navigation tools for your end user. How would you want to navigate your content?

You can have up to three or four sections (the 4th is reserved for 'Saved' content, and the 5th for subscriptions, if you so choose to have them). It's important to note that each section name can be no longer than 25 characters. To see the full list of available icons, take a look at Section Icons page.

articles.name: TV Platform Asset Specs
articles.title: TV Platform Asset Specs
articles.body:
General TV Assets

Launch Logo - 1200 x 600p, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Logo - Height 150px, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Launch Screen - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Image/Skin - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Video Loop - up to 5 second duration, no more than 200 mb, MOV or MP4

Apple TV Assets

Apple TV Icon - 1280 x 768p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Top Shelf Image - 2320 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080 px, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Assets

Roku App Icon (HD) - 336 x 210p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku App Icon (SD) - 248 x 140p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Search Poster (FHD) - 540 x 405p, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Screenshots - 1920 x 1080p, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Assets

Android TV Icon - 512 x 512p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Feature Graphic - 1024 x 500p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG, JPG, JPEG

Android TV Banner - 1280 x 720 px, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG, JPG, JPEG

Amazon Fire TV Assets

Fire TV Icon - 1280 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Fire TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080px, 3 required and up to 8, 72 dpi, PNG

Description Character Limits

Apple App Description: 4000 characters

Amazon App Description: 2000 characters

Google Play Short Description: 80 characters

Roky Description: 300 characters

Keywords: 99 characters

Copyright: 199 characters

articles.name: Getting Started: Endpoints and Endpoint Setup
articles.title: Getting Started: Endpoints and Endpoint Setup
articles.body:
Within Distribution Dashboard — is where you choose and monitor the platforms you want to publish your app to (Endpoints), as well as upload various assets and app information that are necessary for creating a NewsX app (Endpoint Setup).

___________________________________________

Endpoints:

This is where you toggle on/off the endpoints you want to output your content to. This will also be a useful dashboard during the entire process of building, testing, submitting, and seeing an app through pending and going live.

Building and to Test will appear orange, signifying the ability to continue editing and finessing your app.

Submitting and Pending will appear yellow, meaning these are in the App Store waiting to go live.

Live will be green.

As new versions are being built, you will see two statuses per endpoint, one will be your Live app, and below, the status of the next update.


Endpoint Setup:

After you choose your endpoints, you can head into Endpoint Setup. You'll see on the dropdown menu all the app stores that require data and information in order to submit your apps.

Description

Let your potential downloaders know what they will get out of your app and content. The first few lines should be catchy and pull readers in. This is critical to converting would-be downloaders into active users. Keep in mind, app store visitors will only see the first four lines of your description before expanding it. Make them count. Then, you will also need to choose your App Store Name, which is limited to 30 characters. This is the name that will display inside of the app stores, and can be different or the same from the app name. Note that the app store name will automatically be considered a searchable keyword.

Primary Category

This will be used for indexing your app in the store. If a user is perusing the app store by category, this is where they would find you. Most users, however, use the search function to find apps so don't overthink it.

Secondary Category

It is not mandatory to add a secondary category, but if you feel your content can't be put into a box, feel free to choose another category.

Keywords

Keywords in the app store work just like a search engine. Consider what words your target audience might use to find you. Keep it simple. You only have 100 characters to spare. There is no need to use phrases or repeat keywords. Also, keep in mind that your app store name is automatically considered a keyword.

Copyright

This should be the entity that controls the copyright for your content.

Google Analytics Tracking ID

Ok, this isn't exactly relevant to the app store, but don't you want to know what your app users are doing? This ID number will allow you to gather analytics info about your app. Important: this ID is different than the tracking ID for your website. For more information on how to create your mobile app tracking ID, please visit the Google Analytics Tracking ID page.

Content Rating

When submitting your app, Apple will designate an age rating from 4+ up to 17+. If you have content that could be deemed 17+, please let us know using this dropdown.

Subscriptions

Here is where you choose whether your app will have subscription options (toggle On/Off). If you choose On, you'll then be prompted to choose the Type, Title, Labels, and prices of the various subscriptions. Once you choose these items, you can go into App Creator, and from there into App Design, to Metering + CTA to work on the UI and language of your metering prompts.

___________________________________________

Mobile and Tablet Assets

App Icon: 1024p x 1024p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

App Logo (in-app): Height 132 px, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

Launch Logo (in-app): 1200p x 600p, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple App Assets

iPad Pro screenshots (up to 5): 2048p x 2732p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

iPhone 6+ screenshots (up to 5): 1242p x 2208p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple Watch screenshots (up to 5): 312 x 390px, 72 dpi, PNG

Android App Assets

Google Play screenshots (min of 2, max of 8): 320p x 480p

Google Play Feature Graphic: 1024p x 500p

Amazon screenshots (min of 3, max of 10): 480p x 800p


Description Character Limits

Apple App Description: 4000 characters

Amazon App Description: 2000 characters

Google Play Short Description: 80 characters

Keywords: 99 characters

Copyright: 199 characters

General TV Assets

Launch Logo - 1200 x 600p, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Logo - Height 150px, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Launch Screen - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Image/Skin - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Video Loop - up to 5 second duration, no more than 200 mb, MOV or MP4

Apple TV Assets

Apple TV Icon - 1280 x 768p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Top Shelf Image - 2320 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080 px, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Assets

Roku App Icon (HD) - 336 x 210p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku App Icon (SD) - 248 x 140p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Search Poster (FHD) - 540 x 405p, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Screenshots - 1920 x 1080p, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Assets

Android TV Icon - 512 x 512p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Feature Graphic - 1024 x 500p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG, JPG, JPEG

Android TV Banner - 1280 x 720 px, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG, JPG, JPEG

Amazon Fire TV Assets

Fire TV Icon - 1280 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Fire TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080px, 3 required and up to 8, 72 dpi, PNG

Description Character Limits

Apple App Description: 4000 characters

Amazon App Description: 2000 characters

Google Play Short Description: 80 characters

Roky Description: 300 characters

Keywords: 99 characters

Copyright: 199 characters

___________________________________________

Screenshots

These screenshots are as important if not more so than the app description. Beautiful, captivating pictures of your content will drive app downloads and, in turn, sales. A few things to keep in mind when uploading these screenshots:

- There are three required screenshot sizes (take a look at our Screenshot Specs page for details)

- You only need one of each size screenshot, but can have up to five.

- Your app may be rejected if the screenshots misrepresent the in-app experience (iPad screenshot for the Apple Watch app)

articles.name: Getting Started: Banners
articles.title: Getting Started: Banners
articles.body:
From Experience Creator, you'll see Banners, your spot for setting up Banners and Banner Groups.

For both Mobile and TV, you can upload Banner images at 2048x450p, 72dpi, PNG or JPG right here. For mobile, you can put in a Link Type to open to when someone clicks the banner, and for TV, put in a Deep Link to bring a user elsewhere in the app.

In Experience Creator, you'll be able to select different Banner Groups to display per section or sub section.

articles.name: Getting Started: Media Manager
articles.title: Getting Started: Media Manager
articles.body:
Media Manager is a CMS tool for authoring articles or creating image galleries right in MAZ Control. This tool is useful in Feed Builder and for anyone utilizing PDF to Feed. It's also great for on-the-fly updates to the content in your app, or created targeted "Instant Issues" or feeds. It's easy too! Simply hover over Nav to get to Media Manager...

Once there you can organize your Drafts as well as Published, and you can choose to +Media or +Folder.

The types of media you can choose to create are Article, Image or Smart Feed --

If you choose to create an article... you simply, add Title, Subtitle, Description, Tags, and Feed Image (horizontal or vertical 300x300p 72 dpi JPG). Then you add in a Headline, Byline and Visible Date and Body of the article. Voila!

If you choose to add an image...you simply, add Title, Subtitle, Description, Tags, and Feed Image (horizontal or vertical 300x300p 72 dpi JPG). Then you Upload your Image and add a Caption!

If you choose to add a Smart Feed, you choose a Title, Subtitle, Description, and input Search Tags. These search tags will filter through your content headlines, article body, and meta tags to create a filtered "Smart Feed" that you can utilize on the fly, no app update required - in the instance of breaking news, event coverage, holiday coverage, and more. Any Smart Feed you create will show up in your dropdown menu in +Content in Experience Creator.

articles.name: Banners, Sponsor Screens, In-App Purchases
articles.title: Banners, Sponsor Screens, In-App Purchases
articles.body:
Here are some ways to visualize your Banners, Sponsor Screens and In-App Purchases.

Banners: Access Banners through Ad Center (dropdown in Experience Creator), click +Banner, and upload your Banner Image (1966x400p, 72dpi, PNG or JPG), choose where visible (TV + Mobile/Tablet), insert Tracking Name, and Deeplink.

Sponsor Screens: Access Sponsor Screen through Ad Center, click +Screen. Choose where visible (TV + Mobile/Tablet), insert Tracking Name, upload Sponsor Logo (1200x600p, transparent background, 72dpi, PNG, max size 1MB), choose Background Type (Single Color, Gradient, or Image) and then choose colors or upload image accordingly. Choose duration time of screen (between 1-5 seconds).

In-App Purchases: You'll be able to choose In-App Purchases per section, content or item within App Creator...

articles.name: Adding a Section
articles.title: Adding a Section
articles.body:
How to Add a Section

1. Go to the Experience Creator and click "+ Section"

2. Determine the platform(s) that this section will be visible on (TV, and/or Mobile+Tablet)

3. Proceed filling out the form (see Section vocabulary below)

4. Click 'Save'

Visible On - Select to show this section on Mobile/Tablet, TV or both. Keep in mind, a section that is going to be displayed on TV can only contain video content.

Active - We have made it easy to turn a section on/off. If this box is checked and a section is Active, the button will display along the bottom of the app. If this box not checked, it will not be visible to the end user.

Show Banners - Determine whether or not banners will be displayed in this section of the app. For more information on banners, take a look the Banners page.

Sponsored - Determine if the section will be marked as a sponsored area of the app.

Name - The section name will be displayed differently on each platform. On mobile/tablet, the name will exist directly underneath the corresponding section icon. On TV, the section name will be displayed in the top navigation bar.

Advanced Options

Deeplinking - If you would like a section button to open a specific sub-section, you can create a deep-link to it. As of now, you can only deep-link to another menu within the same section.

articles.name: Getting Started: Analytics Panel
articles.title: Getting Started: Analytics Panel
articles.body:
Analytics is where we report the essential metrics:
-Stores, for app downloads, single purchases and subscription purchases straight from your app store developer accounts. You can sort by month and App Store.

-Engagement, which leads to your Google Analytics dashboard.

-Settings, to update your analytics settings.

For all other usage data, please refer to Google Analytics.

articles.name: Getting Started: Notification Wizard
articles.title: Getting Started: Notification Wizard
articles.body:
Notification Wizard is your go to for Push Notifications. You can author new notifications, schedule them, and see how they performed.

Once you create a Push Notification, you can manage drafts and scheduled ones in the dashboard. Push Notifications are one of the top marketing tools you can utilize to keep your users engaged and informed of news and updates. We see Push Notifications bringing 2X the amount of sessions to an app on days they're sent out. Definitely give it a try if you haven't yet, in order to enable, please reach out to support@mazdigital.com.

Authoring Push Notifications is easy - give it a Tracking Name, put in the Text Copy, choose a Link to bring a user to (if any), and then schedule the time/date/platform you want it sent to.

Note at the bottom left, you can set "Available in All Countries" in order to send specific push notifications to specific countries or continents, known as Geo Push. This feature is great for location based news or information. In order to see this option, go into Distribution Dashboard's "Geo Fencing" section and toggle "Display All Content In All Countries" from Yes to No.

articles.name: Getting Started: Ad Center
articles.title: Getting Started: Ad Center
articles.body:
Ad Center is your place for everything related to Sponsor Screen and Third Party Ad Settings related.

Add a Sponsor Screen on both TV and Mobile. This will show upon launching an app and you can choose the duration, the color, upload an image at 1200x600p, transparent, 72dpi, PNG. And can put in Action Buttons as well.

Then you can click into Ad Center to control your own ad integration feeds including DFP, SpotX, Gigya and Taboola. You can now show ads in the category and sub-category setup only if you have enabled them within the AdCenter. If you don’t see them showing check first to see it’s enabled.

Disable and Enable your various integrations to put in the correct tracking information, frequency, duration, and such. More in depth Ad information coming in designated article...

articles.name: TV Platform Asset Specs
articles.title: TV Platform Asset Specs
articles.body:
General TV Assets

Launch Logo - 1200 x 600p, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Launch Screen - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Image/Skin - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Video Loop - up to 5 second duration, no more than 200 mb, MOV or MP4

Top Shelf Image - 2320 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080 px, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku App Icon (SD) - 248 x 140p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Search Poster (FHD) - 540 x 405p, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Screenshots - 1920 x 1080p, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Assets

Google Play Short Description: 80 characters

Keywords: 99 characters

articles.name: Getting Started: Experience Creator
articles.title: Getting Started: Experience Creator
articles.body:
Experience Creator is where you set up your Phoenix app. This includes: UI Design, + Section and + Content, as well as Notification Wizard (where you schedule out push notifications), Banners (to create banner groups), and Ad Center (your ad settings).

UI Design - on the top left when you enter Experience Creator, and also in the dropdown menu:

Once your in UI Design, you'll be able to design nearly every aspect of your UI, by toggling the top right options.

You can choose from General Interface, Saved Section, Metering + Call To Action, Subscribe Section, User Registration, Apple Watch and iOS Widget:

Go into the DESIGN articles for in depth explanation on each of these and what that looks like!

Once you choose your App Design, you can start building out your app. Create +Section and +Content, choose the icons, choose your content type, choose your app themes. This is the fun part!

+Section is how you begin creating the content silos for your app. You can name your section anything, from Magazine, News, Video, to Recipes, Photography, Shopping, to Top 10, Editor's Choice, to whatever you want. Choose if you want this section visible on Mobile/Tablet, TV, if you want it to be active in the app, to show banners, and be a sponsored Section.

Once you've created a few Sections, you can make them Active, you can edit them per platform, and if you click into a specific one, you can edit the design and add content (or create sub-sections for more in depth hierarchy).

For example, tap into 5 Minute Yoga, you will be shown an option to "Edit Design" or add another Section or add Content.

If you click "Edit Design", you can change the icon from the default. Choosing a camera for Photography...

There are a lot of Section Icons to choose from!

Then you can choose your theme --

When you tap +Content, you have to Name your content, and choose your Content Type.

Phoenix supports RSS/Atom, MRSS, Feed Builder, Smart Feed, PDF to Feed, PDF Only, Simulated Live Video, hPub, JSON and Vimeo.

Once the type of content is chosen, you add in the rest of the information pertaining to your content:

Decide if the Content is Free or Locked, Sub-Title, Description. Choose the Layout, Images, Logos, Ad Options, and more. We will go much more in depth on Section and Content in posts dedicated just to those! For now, welcome to Experience Creator.

articles.name: Getting Started: Endpoints and Endpoint Setup
articles.title: Getting Started: Endpoints and Endpoint Setup
articles.body:
Within Distribution Dashboard — is where you choose and monitor the platforms you want to publish your app to (Endpoints), as well as upload various assets and app information that are necessary for creating a Phoenix app (Endpoint Setup).

___________________________________________

Endpoints:

This is where you toggle on/off the endpoints you want to output your content to. This will also be a useful dashboard during the entire process of building, testing, submitting, and seeing an app through pending and going live.

Building and to Test will appear orange, signifying the ability to continue editing and finessing your app.

Submitting and Pending will appear yellow, meaning these are in the App Store waiting to go live.

Live will be green.

As new versions are being built, you will see two statuses per endpoint, one will be your Live app, and below, the status of the next update.


Endpoint Setup:

After you choose your endpoints, you can head into Endpoint Setup. You'll see on the dropdown menu all the app stores that require data and information in order to submit your apps.

Description

Let your potential downloaders know what they will get out of your app and content. The first few lines should be catchy and pull readers in. This is critical to converting would-be downloaders into active users. Keep in mind, app store visitors will only see the first four lines of your description before expanding it. Make them count. Then, you will also need to choose your App Store Name, which is limited to 30 characters. This is the name that will display inside of the app stores, and can be different or the same from the app name. Note that the app store name will automatically be considered a searchable keyword.

Primary Category

This will be used for indexing your app in the store. If a user is perusing the app store by category, this is where they would find you. Most users, however, use the search function to find apps so don't overthink it.

Secondary Category

It is not mandatory to add a secondary category, but if you feel your content can't be put into a box, feel free to choose another category.

Keywords

Keywords in the app store work just like a search engine. Consider what words your target audience might use to find you. Keep it simple. You only have 100 characters to spare. There is no need to use phrases or repeat keywords. Also, keep in mind that your app store name is automatically considered a keyword.

Copyright

This should be the entity that controls the copyright for your content.

Google Analytics Tracking ID

Ok, this isn't exactly relevant to the app store, but don't you want to know what your app users are doing? This ID number will allow you to gather analytics info about your app. Important: this ID is different than the tracking ID for your website. For more information on how to create your mobile app tracking ID, please visit the Google Analytics Tracking ID page.

Content Rating

When submitting your app, Apple will designate an age rating from 4+ up to 17+. If you have content that could be deemed 17+, please let us know using this dropdown.

Subscriptions

Here is where you choose whether your app will have subscription options (toggle On/Off). If you choose On, you'll then be prompted to choose the Type, Title, Labels, and prices of the various subscriptions. Once you choose these items, you can go into App Creator, and from there into App Design, to Metering + CTA to work on the UI and language of your metering prompts.

___________________________________________

Mobile and Tablet Assets

App Icon: 1024p x 1024p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

App Logo (in-app): Height 132 px, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

Launch Logo (in-app): 1200p x 600p, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple App Assets

iPad Pro screenshots (up to 5): 2048p x 2732p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

iPhone 6+ screenshots (up to 5): 1242p x 2208p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple Watch screenshots (up to 5): 312 x 390px, 72 dpi, PNG

Android App Assets

Google Play screenshots (min of 2, max of 8): 320p x 480p

Google Play Feature Graphic: 1024p x 500p

Amazon screenshots (min of 3, max of 10): 480p x 800p


Description Character Limits

Apple App Description: 4000 characters

Amazon App Description: 2000 characters

Google Play Short Description: 80 characters

Keywords: 99 characters

Copyright: 199 characters

General TV Assets

Launch Logo - 1200 x 600p, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Logo - Height 150px, transparent background, 72 dpi, PNG

TV Launch Screen - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Image/Skin - 1920 x 1080p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Background Video Loop - up to 5 second duration, no more than 200 mb, MOV or MP4

Apple TV Assets

Apple TV Icon - 1280 x 768p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Top Shelf Image - 2320 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Apple TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080 px, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Assets

Roku App Icon (HD) - 336 x 210p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku App Icon (SD) - 248 x 140p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Search Poster (FHD) - 540 x 405p, 72 dpi, PNG

Roku Screenshots - 1920 x 1080p, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Assets

Android TV Icon - 512 x 512p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Android TV Feature Graphic - 1024 x 500p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG, JPG, JPEG

Android TV Banner - 1280 x 720 px, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG, JPG, JPEG

Amazon Fire TV Assets

Fire TV Icon - 1280 x 720p, no transparency, 72 dpi, PNG

Fire TV Screenshots - 1920 x 1080px, 3 required and up to 8, 72 dpi, PNG

Description Character Limits

Apple App Description: 4000 characters

Amazon App Description: 2000 characters

Google Play Short Description: 80 characters

Roky Description: 300 characters

Keywords: 99 characters

Copyright: 199 characters

___________________________________________

Screenshots

These screenshots are as important if not more so than the app description. Beautiful, captivating pictures of your content will drive app downloads and, in turn, sales. A few things to keep in mind when uploading these screenshots:

- There are three required screenshot sizes (take a look at our Screenshot Specs page for details)

- You only need one of each size screenshot, but can have up to five.

- Your app may be rejected if the screenshots misrepresent the in-app experience (iPad screenshot for the Apple Watch app)

articles.name: Creating Subscriptions
articles.title: Creating Subscriptions
articles.body:
Adding subscriptions to your app

**If you can't access the Distribution Dashboard section, click 'Add Credit Card' in MAZ Control and fill out the form. Once completed, you will have access to Subscriptions.**

In Distribution Dashboard, you can manage your Subscriptions.

There, you choose to offer Subscription Purchases or not:

2. Under 'Subscription Type' determine what is unlocked with a subscription. 'Duration-Based' will unlock content that is released within the dates of their subscription. 'All-Access' will unlock all content inside of the app as long as the subscription remains active.

3. Determine the duration of subscriptions available and their corresponding cost. It makes sense to provide some added value to subscribing versus one-off purchases.

4. Scroll down and click 'Save'.

*Note, you'll be able to edit the copy and design of your Subscription UI in Experience Creator, UI Design.

Subscriptions Vocabulary

Feed Label - Determine how the app will refer to a feed of content. In example below, they have labeled it an 'issue' (as in "Unlock this ____")

All Access - Subscribers will have access to all content in the app.

Duration Based - Subscribers are granted access to a selection of feeds based on a date range. If a feed's cover date falls within the subscription dates, the content will be available to the subscriber.

Subscription Title - Determine what the bottom, right section button will be titled. Here it is labeled as 'Subscription'.

Subscription Label - Determine what language will be used in reference to feed. Here they have labeled the subscription as 'Access'.

articles.name: Setting up a Google Tracking ID
articles.title: Setting up a Google Tracking ID
articles.body:
Google Analytics

Connecting a Google Analytics account with your app is critical. It's the only way to gather info about app usage and user behavior. Also, it's important to know that until you add this tracking ID, no data will be tracked. In other words, this data will not be added to your Google Analytics account retroactively.

Follow these instructions for setting up your tracking ID.

1. Go to www.google.com/analytics

Sign in with the Google account you would like to be associated with the app analytics. If your website already has a Google Analytics account, you should use the same log in. This will keep your analytics consolidated. If you do not have an account, create a new account and follow the on-screen instructions.

2. Under new account, select 'Mobile app'

It is critical that you select 'Mobile app' to ensure we are sending the correct type of analytics. If you leave the selection as 'Website', we will not be able to report analytics to the account.

3. Add Account Name and App Name

These are for your internal use only. Use whatever naming convention you feel comfortable with.

4. Select Industry Category and Reporting Time Zone

Google uses the industry category to improve analytics and provide more focused advice. The timezone selection will determine the timeframe used to segment data.

5. Click 'Get Tracking ID'

Once you have your new ID, copy+paste it in MAZ Control. If your app is already active, you will need to email your new tracking ID to accounts@mazdigital.com to add it to your account.

There is one more step to ensure we are collecting all relevant information from your app.

6. Enable Ecommerce Tracking

Click Admin > Click Ecommerce Settings > Turn on Ecommerce. Congratulations! Your Google Analytics tracking set up is complete. Now take a look at our Google Analytics Basics page and start to get familiar with inner workings of Google Analytics.

articles.name: Phoenix Viewer App: Simulator
articles.title: Phoenix Viewer App: Simulator
articles.body:
The Phoenix Viewer App
1. Download the Phoenix Viewer app on your iPhone or iPad. App icon below.
2. Open the app, and login using your email address and your account code (found in the Simulator section of MAZ Control). The preview app will simulate a real end user's experience once you log in once.
3. When you make a change in MAZ Control, be sure to click Save then tap the 'Refresh' button in the Viewer app. Changes are typically instantaneous, but it can take a minute or so to load after refreshing.

articles.name: PDF Link Recognition
articles.title: PDF Link Recognition
articles.body:
When processing your files, MAZ will recognize all links that are already baked into your PDF. This includes any links that have been manually added to the PDF in your design software of choice. After the issue's been processed, MAZ Control's Link Editor will help you further enrich your content with links, buttons, streaming capabilities and more.

If the text of your PDF has some URLs or email addresses you'd like to turn into links automatically, Acrobat Pro and InDesign can be very helpful. For a step-by-step guide for how to prepare your PDF with auto-links and then upload it through MAZ Control, please download the guide below for the software you use:

articles.name: MAZ PDF App Info
articles.title: MAZ PDF App Info
articles.body:
App Name is the name that will be displayed on the device under your app icon. It can be the same as or different than your App Store name. [13 character limit]

App Store Name is the name that will be displayed in the App Stores before it is downloaded. It can be the same as or different than your App Name. Please leave blank if you would like it the same as the App Name.

Description is what will be displayed in all of the App Stores for prospective customers, as well as in the app under the “About Us” section. [4000 character limit]
Primary Category and Secondary Category each provide a list of categories to help customers discover your app in the App Stores.
Keywords are words and phrases that can help get your app in front of users searching for such terms on the App Stores. Please separate keywords using commas. [100 character limit]
Copyright is where you should enter any pertinent copyright information for your app. [1024 character limit]

App Defaults determine what users see when they first open your app:

  • Storefront View - All the issues of your magazine be displayed in Grid View, Stack View, or Stream View

  • Auto Open - What you choose for Storefront view will open every time your user opens the app.
Website is the URL accessible from within the app when users tap on “Visit Website,” and will also be linked from your listing in the App Stores. If your website solicits donations, Apple requires that the website launch in Safari instead of inside the app itself.
Twitter Handle is your complete Twitter handle. If your Twitter URL were twitter.com/mazdigital, then you would enter 'mazdigital' in this field. We use this to integrate your Twitter feed into your app.
App Ratings are an age-appropriate rating Apple assigns your app depending on its content. The ratings are 4+, 9+, 12+, or 17+.
  • Cartoon or Fantasy Violence refers to unrealistic depictions of pain or violence.
  • Realistic Violence refers to graphic and believable depictions of pain or violence.
  • Nudity or Sexual Content refers to depictions of sexual activity or nudity of any kind.
  • Profanity or Crude Humor refers to the use of cuss words, or otherwise crass language.
  • Alcohol, Tobacco or Drugs refers to the presence of controversial substances of any kind.
  • Mature or Suggestive Themes is a general catch-all that can be thought of as a sum of all the other categories.
  • Simulated Gambling refers to any in-app simulation or glorification of betting.
  • Horror or Fear Themes refers to any depiction, real or fictional, of deliberately frightening content.
  • Graphic Realistic Violence and Graphic Sexual/Nudity are banned by Apple standards. We cannot approve apps with content of this nature. If you submit anything with this type of content you will be removed from MAZ without refund or warning.

App Info | Sales | Assets

articles.name: Creating a New App on MAZ Control
articles.title: Creating a New App on MAZ Control
articles.body:
Welcome to MAZ Control!

MAZ Control is where you will build, design and create your app. Upon your first login, you will be prompted to choose the type of app you're creating:

TVX is our OTT platform, for TV broadcast and video publishers. Our OTT apps allow for infinite levels of series and episodic hierarchy, as well as shared saving between mobile and TV, and supports live streaming. TVX outputs to Apple TV, Roku, Amazon Fire TV, Chromecast, Android TV, iOS, Google Play, Amazon Kindle Fire, Apple Watch, and soon to include all OEM and HTML5.

NewsX is built specifically for breaking news organizations focusing on realtime updates and livestream video. NewsX outputs to mobile, tablet, OTT and Apple Watch and in inclusive of all types of paywall and subscription options: metered based and time based. NewsX can output by region and continent, utilizing our Geo Fencing tech. By opting into our Push Notification system, livestream video, and Smart Feed: On-the-fly editorials, your users and content are covered.

Phoenix is our mobile first magazine and web app. Phoenix was built for mobile, accepting web feeds, video feeds, PDF, and includes a build-your-own "Feed Builder" as well as room to author articles in our "Media Manager." Phoenix emphasizes feeds to bring people into your app on a daily basis for constant new content. Our Phoenix apps output to Apple TV, Roku, Amazon Fire TV, Chromecast, Android TV, iOS, Google Play, Amazon Kindle Fire, and Apple Watch.

MAZ PDF is our classic PDF magazine app. Built for tablet and mobile, it also supports web-feeds and social icons to become a brand hub for your periodical. MAZ PDF outputs to iOS, Google Play, Amazon Kindle Fire, Apple Watch, and HTML5.

articles.name: Adding a PDF
articles.title: Adding a PDF
articles.body:
Adding Content to your app is simple. All you have to do is upload your PDF and enter its info.

Upload Your Content

MAZ is a "what you see is what you get" solution, so it's important to make sure your PDF is optimal before submitting it. MAZ makes it easy to use your pre-existing PDFs, but we recommend:

  • Page dimensions of 768 by 1004 pixels, width by height, to optimize for Portrait view. (Or bigger, as long as you keep this ratio.)
  • Page dimensions of 1024 by 748 pixels, width by height, to optimize for Landscape view. (Or bigger, as long as you keep this ratio.)
  • A print-quality PDF (300dpi).
  • No bleeds, crops, or other printer's marks.
  • A file size of 200 MB or less. If your PDF is a little larger it will still work, but try to stay within this limit.

Once your PDF is ready to go:

  • Log into MAZ and mouse over the "Content" button in the navigation bar.
  • Select "New," then choose the appropriate PDF file from your harddrive.
  • Depending on the size of the file, the upload may take some time to complete. Please make sure you have a strong internet connection before beginning your upload, and do not leave the page while the PDF is uploading.


Edit Info

During or after your upload, you can click on the "Info" tab and begin entering details for your new Content. The tip column on the right side of the form features pictures illustrating each step, so be sure to look there if you'd like visual cues to help you along.

Content Name is the title will be displayed in the app for this piece of Content. [32 character limit]

Apple Price is the price for this particular piece of Content in the Apple App Store, set in USD. In the app world, it's generally good practice to have consistent pricing, and to offer some free Content as a promotional giveaway.

Android Price is the same, except for the Google Play and Kindle Fire stores. Please use USD here, as well.

Cover Date is your Content's cover date. If you offer subscriptions, cover dates are used to determine which Content is included in a subscription.

Digital Release Date is not visible to your readers, but it determines when the Content will be released within your app.

Landscape Default is what readers will automatically see when they turn their device horizontally for reading purposes. 2-Page Landscape is the industry standard, but if you’d rather have it simply zoom in for the current page, select 1-Page.

Description is the text that will be displayed beside your Content in the app. [190 character limit, 10 character minimum]

Publish To is where you determine if you'd like to publish this Content exclusively to Apple iOS, exclusively to Android, or to both. The Android option is only available if you have a Multi-Platform or Enterprise account with MAZ.
